p: Welcome to the Shopify ↔ Orderwise Integration App documentation. This comprehensive guide will help you set up and configure the Shopwise app to seamlessly integrate your Shopify store with your Orderwise system.
Shopwise is a powerful integration app that connects your Shopify store with Orderwise, enabling:
Order Synchronization- Automatically send orders from Shopify to Orderwise
Inventory Management- Keep stock levels synchronized between platforms
Status Updates- Track order status changes across both systems
Product Mapping- Sync product data and attributes
Payment & Shipping Mapping- Ensure proper order processing
Getting Started- Initial setup and configuration
Session Setup- Configure Orderwise e-commerce session
Orderwise Integration- Complete integration setup
Troubleshooting- Common issues and solutions
Automatically transfer orders from Shopify to Orderwise with proper mapping of customers, products, and payment methods.
Keep your Shopify stock levels updated with real-time data from Orderwise using configurable export definitions.
Map Orderwise order statuses to Shopify's fulfillment states (Fulfilled, Cancelled, Refunded).
Sync product information, pricing, and attributes between systems using customizable field mappings.
Configure payment methods and shipping options to ensure orders process correctly in Orderwise.
Check the Troubleshooting Guide for common issues
Review the Log Manager section for debugging
Ensure all prerequisites are met before starting setup
Ready to get started? Begin with the Getting Started Guide to set up your integration.
This repository contains Magento, themes and modules backing the customised Magento setup
For a quicker start there is Docker setup.
Docker
docker-compose
awscli(configured) - I have v1, but it should work with v2
node- >= LTS version

At some point of initial setup Compoer will ask you about repository details. You can find a credentials for each repository as described below. Some of the repositories requires opening the page, using existing or creating new key. Other repository credentials may be saved directly in LastPass
Composer will ask you if it can save details in a file. Feel free to do so.
Github- use private account
Magento Marketplace
Amasty
MageWorx
Ebizmarts- username: token, password in LastPass
repository.kingfisherdirect.co.uk- credentials in LastPass
Clone this repository
Clone docker compose files to folder outside this repository git clone https://gitlab.com/lumnn/magento2-docker-compose.git
Navigate to repository from step 2 and generate self-signed ssl certificate by running bin/create-self-signed-ssl
Ensure composer config directory is existing on your system mkdir -p ~/.config/composer
Navigate to folder where repository from step 1 was cloned into.
Create .env file for docker compose cp .env.sample .env
Update .env file with correct path to docker-compose.yml from repo cloned in step 2.
Start environment docker compose up
Create magento env.php file bin/setup-magento
This is not everything. You'll need to also follow steps below.
Above preparing environment steps are one-time only steps. Following ones you will execute more often to keep your environment updated.
Install composer dependencies docker compose exec php composer install
Import database
Run upgrade after importing database or installing newer composer dependencies docker compose exec php bin/magento setup:upgrade
Compile themes stylesheets
pushd src/src/directwatertanks-theme npm install popd
pushd src/src/kingfisherdirect-theme-2020 npm install popd
pushd src/src/gritbins-22 npm install popd
In order to work with themes jump to Theme Development section
After the Installation steps are completed you can start developing. To stop environment simply CTRL + C on the docker-compose up command.

Next time to start project simply run docker-compose up and you're ready to go. Time to time you may need to install latest composer changes or update your database with more recent live website data.
docker compose exec php bin/magento or bin/magento
Command that alows speed up certain actions. Run without parameters to get a list of available commands
docker compose exec php composer or bin/composer
Because we use docker for development you have to run composer in a docker. That's why there is a script for that
After starting docker-compose there is Mailcatcher service running to find it's url run:
docker compose ps
Find line with mailcatcher
Find IP:Port that points to 1080 (for example 0.0.0.0:32775-1080), which states port to use (in this example 32775). Then navigate to either http://0.0.0.0:PORT or http://localhost:PORT
By default magento is setup to load live images. Although it's alright for most cases sometimes it can cause issues. To get images working locally you need to follow these steps:
Paste theese lines in env/magento.local.env. You may add more if there is more websites
Restart containers
Download images using bin/download-media. Script should guide you through the process
See bin folder for more scripts.
If you want create scripts for personal environment just prepend them with 'my-'. For example: bin/my-start. It will be ignored by git
Magento is using XML file format for configurations. Setting up a XML linter or getting auto completitions is not straight forward for everything else than PHPStorm.
In order to use that with SublimeText or VSCode you can follow these steps.
VS Code
Install this extension - https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=redhat.vscode-xml
Run bin/generate-urn with docker-compose beeing up
Open Extension Settings panel in VS Code
Switch to Workspace tab (scope)
Add to "XML: Catalogs" a path src/var/magento_urn_oasis.xml
Sublime Text
Instal packages: LSP and LSP-lemminx
Ensure you opened project folder as Sublime Text project, not just by open folder. (You can create project, by opening folder and then: Project > Save Project As..)
Configure you .sublime-project by merging this JSON into existing contents
Read about PHP Coding Standard on Magento Docs
Setting this up will enforce same as in Magento rules.
VS Code
Install this extension https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=obliviousharmony.vscode-php-codesniffer
Install PHP in similar as bin/cli php -v version on your system globally
Open Extension Settings panel in VS Code
Switch to Workspace tab (scope)
Set Executable to: php src/vendor/bin/phpcs( php may be changed to php7 or similar on some systems)
Set Standard to: Custom
Set Standard Custom to: src/.phpcs.xml.dist
Sublime Text
Install SublimeLinter and SublimeLinter-phpcs packages
Merge this config into your *.sublime-project

For PHP completitions and other useful helping features you can install phpactor by downloading VSCode extension and installing directly the .VSIX file https://github.com/phpactor/vscode-phpactor/releases/

Then you have to modify it's configuration to take most of it. Go to extension settings, switch to workspace tab and then set phpactor.config value using the following template. First path has to be absolute path to the src folder inside this project folder.
We use Magepack to optimize frontend performance.
In order for it to work correctly this command needs to be executed every time any of JS set-up changes (adding/removing/updating modules, changing templates and it's JS dependencies etc.)
bin/magepack-generate-config
To start debugging you need to start docker with ENV variable XDEBUG_ENABLE=1. To do that you can simply run XDEBUG_MODE=develop,debug docker-compose up.
To run debugger you need to trigger request with XDEBUG_TRIGGER variable sent with POST, GET or COOKIE. For this you may use Xdebug extensions for browsers.
Optionally you can configure it to start automatically XDEBUG_CONFIG=start_with_request=yes. This can be either passed to command or saved in your .env file.
Xdebug will work on localhost:9003 and that's how you should configure your IDE.
Example configuration for VS Code.

At the moment themes lives in src/src/* folders. Ideally they should be split between repositories, however that would require time invested into setup and learning how to set it up in effective for everyone way.
Each theme at the moment comes with package.json- a NPM package definition file, which describes dependencies and the way how the theme should be built.
The theme build/dev process is based on 2 npm commands withing appropriate theme:- npm run build- to build theme entirely- npm run dev- to work on styles in watch mode
More theme-specific instructions should be described in themes README.md.
It's easy to get something not working in magento, so here's a list of things to do in first place to resolve problems:
Clean Cache - bin/magento cache:clear
Check Logs - src/var/logs/debug.log
Clean all generated files and caches - bin/advanced-clean
Check if all docker containers are working - docker-compose ps
Clean browser cache
Run - bin/magento setup:upgrade
Restart computer
There may be few reasons for that. And also few solutions:
Ensure Magento cache is enabled (there is many of them)
Set to production mode if you're not developing anything bin/magento deploy:mode:set production
Or at least to default mode bin/magento deploy:mode:set default
Ensure caches are enabled bin/magento cache:status
Check Logs - src/var/logs/debug.log contains all logs
Upgrade to linux as Windows environment will handle both Magento and Docker MUCH slower. Not tested on macOS at all
Upgrade to SSD

l: Both Including and Excluding Tax Price Fixes
p: This module is meant to fix few issues when configuration is set to display both including end excluding tax prices.
displaying both prices doesn't affect regular price when special price is beeing shown (there is missing excl. tax regular price).
This module will affect Magento behaviour only if it's set to display both prices.
Apart from that you're required to override Magento_Catalog::product/price/final_price.phtml template to set skip_adjustment option to false for oldPrice price.
To display ex. VAT price in Configurable Product options add following mixin in your theme's Magento_ConfigurableProduct/requirejs-config.js

Locate the /app/code directory which should be under the magento root installation.
If the code folder is not there, create it.
Create a folder Loqate inside the code folder.

Change to the Loqate folder and clone the Git repository ( https://github.com/loqate/magento2.git) into Loqate specifying the local repository folder to be Tag e.g. git clone https://github.com/loqate/magento2.git Tag
Locate the /app/code directory which should be under the magento root installation.
If the code folder is not there, create it.
Create the folder structure loqate/Tag/ inside the code folder.
Download the latest release from the github site ( https://github.com/loqate/magento2/releases/).
Extract the zip contents to the Tag folder you just created. The README.md and all other files and folders should be under the Tag folder.
Integrated with Packagist, so you should be able to get the latest version with: composer require loqate/tag:^2.0.8
Make sure you have the correct file and folder permissions set on your magento installation so that the magnento store can install the app.

Refer to the Magento 2 documentation for full instructions on how to install an app, the commands should be similar to the following: php bin/magento setup:upgrade - This tells magento to install the app. php bin/magento cache:flush - This flushes the cache so the app appears in the admin area correctly.
The configuration for the extension is located under Stores> Other Settings> Loqate Settings.
Account Code - Enter your Loqate Account Code here.
Password - The password you used when you setup the account.
Back-end custom javascript - This is for any custom javascript to be injected into the back-end of the website when the app loads.
Front-end custom javascript - This is for any custom javascript to be injected into the front-end of the website when the app loads.

Magento 2 module that provides read-only API permissions for REST API endpoints.

This module creates read-only versions of all ACL resources, allowing you to grant API users GET-only access to endpoints without giving them full permissions. This is useful for integrations that only need to read data from your Magento store.
Automatic ACL Duplication: Creates read-only versions of all ACL resources with _api_ro suffix
GET Request Authorization: Allows GET requests through with read-only permissions when full permissions would normally be required
Admin UI Integration: Adds "API (Read Only)" section in Admin > System > Permissions > User Roles
Security Checks: Maintains HTTPS requirements and backpressure limits
The AclResourceProviderPlugin duplicates all existing ACL resources with:
ID suffix: _api_ro(e.g., Magento_Catalog::products_api_ro)
Title suffix: (RO)(e.g., "Products (RO)")
Organized under: Madmin_Madmin::api_readonly group
The RequestValidatorPlugin intercepts authorization failures for GET requests:
Checks if the request is a GET request
Converts required ACL resources to read-only versions
Authorizes the request if user has read-only permissions
Enforces HTTPS and backpressure requirements
Enable the module:
Create API role in Admin:
Navigate to System > Permissions > User Roles
Create a new role
Under Role Resources, expand "API (Read Only)"
Select the read-only permissions needed
Assign to API user:
Create or edit an integration user
Assign the read-only role
User can now make GET requests to those endpoints
Without this module:
User needs Magento_Catalog::products to GET /rest/V1/products
With this module:
User only needs Magento_Catalog::products_api_ro to GET /rest/V1/products
POST/PUT/DELETE requests still require full permissions

The library provides the ability to customize all of the following user interface elements:

The Magento UI library is a flexible modular Magento frontend library that is designed to assist Magento theme developers. It employs a set of mixins for base elements to ease frontend theme development and customization. The Magento UI library offers the following characteristics for those who develop or customize Magento themes. It is:
tooltips
typography
utilities
Magento UI library is located under /lib/web/ folder. It and employs:
css/ folder where the library files are placed
fonts/ folder where default and icon fonts are placed
images/ folder where default images are placed
jquery/ folder where jQuery and jQuery widgets are placed
Magento UI library employs a variables and mixins naming convention whereby names of variables and mixins describe their purpose or functions they perform.
A variable or a mixins name may only contain lowercase alphanumeric characters, "-" and "_" characters. A variable name must start with "@" character.
If a variable or mixins name consists of more than one word, they must be concatenated with one hyphen character.

A *.less file variable can contain lowercase letters, numbers, special characters: "@", "-" and "_". It must start with "@" character and consist of words concatenated with one hyphen. It should not contain capital letters. A variable name should describe its purpose.
A variable name should be formed according to the following rule:
'@' + 'object' + '-' + 'property' + '-' + 'state' = @object-property-state
If it is a private variable (is used only in a mixin), it must start with "_" character after "@":
'@' + '_' + 'object' + '-' + 'property' + '-' + 'state' = @_object-property-state
Private variables:
A less mixin name can contain lowercase letters, numbers, "-" and "_" characters. It should not contain capital letters.

A mixin name can consist of one or several words, concatenated with one hyphen. If the mixin is private, its name must start with the "_" character. Mixin should be named after property or action it describes.
Please verified that you use spaces instead tabs:
Tab size: 4 spaces
Indent size: 4 spaces
Continuation indent: 4 spaces
Add space before opening brace and line break after. And line break before closing brace.
Add line break after each selector delimiter. Delimeter shouldn't have spaces before and after.
Use single quotes
Use spaces before and after combinators
Use line break for each property declaration
Use no space before property colon, and space after
Each less file should be finished with new line
Each selector should be finished with new line
Each property should be finished with semicolon
Basically avoid use this property at all, but if you really really need it use the following format:
Please follow the next format of comments

According to browser support standards the oldest browser that we support is IE9+, it means that you can feel free to use almost all CSS3 selectors: descendants, attributes, pseudo classes, structural, pseudo elements, etc. Exeption: Please avoid to use id selector.
All classes should be written in lowercase, starts with letter (exept helpers), words in classes should be separated with dash (minus sign '-')
Helper classes should be written in lowercase, starts with underscore ("_")

Use class names that are as short as possible but as long as necessary. Try to convey what class is about while being as brief as possible. Using class names this way contributes to acceptable levels of understandability and code efficiency.
Write selector name together in single line, don't use concatenation
Use meaningful or generic class names.

Instead of presentational or cryptic names, always use class names that reflect the purpose of the element in question, or that are otherwise generic. Names that are specific and reflect the purpose of the element should be preferred as these are most understandable and the least likely to change. Generic names are simply a fallback for elements that have no particular or no meaning different from their siblings. They are typically needed as “helpers.” Using functional or generic names reduces the probability of unnecessary document or template changes.
Avoid qualifying class names with type selectors.
Unless necessary (for example with helper classes), do not use element names in conjunction with IDs or classes. Avoiding unnecessary ancestor selectors is useful for performance reasons.
Use type selectors in lowercase
Be careful with selectors nesting. In general try to use 3 nested levels as max. Exception are pseudo elements and states
Sort all properties alphabetical. Mixins, variables etc. should go first
Use shortland properties where possible.

CSS offers a variety of shorthand properties (like font) that should be used whenever possible, even in cases where only one value is explicitly set. Using shorthand properties is useful for code efficiency and understandability.
Omit unit specification after "0" values.
Omit leading "0"s in values, use dot instead
Use lowercase only
Use 3 character hexadecimal notation where possible.
For color values that permit it, 3 character hexadecimal notation is shorter and more succinct.
Also please avoid hex color in properties, use only variables instead.
If variables are local and used only in module scope it should be located in module file, on the top of the file with general comment
Example _module.less:
If variables are common for couple modules it should be located in _theme.less file
If variables are common for couple themes it should be located in global lib in _variables.less file
All variables should be written in lowercase.
Please mention that component can be not only element name, it also can be primary, secondary, tertiary Base is a modifier

Theme mixins (except extends) should be saved in source/utilities folder Extends that used in more than one theme should be saved in lib lib/source/utilities.less(will be separated into utilities folder)
In name creation you can follow the same rules as for the creation of class names. For mixins grouping use prefix__

Local extends that used only in one file, should be written in this local file. Extends that used in more than two files should be saved in theme source/_extend.less Extends that used in more than one theme should be saved in lib lib/source/_abstract.less(will be renamed to _ extend.less)
Extend class names should have prefix .abs-(from abstract)
The 100% free fork of the world's #1 open source rich text editor.

Used and trusted by millions of developers, TinyMCE(the original project we've forked) is the world’s most customizable, scalable, and flexible rich text editor. However, they changed the license of TinyMCE 7 to GPLv2+ (or a commercial license) while it has been MIT for TinyMCE 6 and LGPL for older versions. This creates problems for users (see the discussion) so a fork has been created here. It has originally been named HugeMCE, however, due to potential trademark confusion with TinyMCE, it has been renamed to HugeRTE before its publishment to npm.
The simplest way to get started with HugeRTE is using a CDN:
Or install it manually via npm:
We're soon going to host the docs for HugeRTE on our website; for now, please refer to the TinyMCE docs, but replace tinymce by hugerte in all code snippets.
See this guide also, but replace tinymce@^6 by hugerte@^1(and of course, all occurrences of tinymce by hugerte).
HugeRTE provides a range of configuration options that allow you to integrate it into your application. Start customizing with a basic setup.
Configure it for one of three modes of editing:
classic editing mode.
inline editing mode.
distraction-free editing mode.

If you have been using TinyMCE before, you have to brute-force replace tinymce by hugerte in your code. In your package.json, make sure you use 1.0.4 as hugerte version – not the one you used for tinymce before. HugeRTE is based on TinyMCE 6.8.4, but it is even later because it contains some code from TinyMCE 7 (all until the commit which changed the license). See the Changelog for details.
We have not yet forked these integrations so they're still about TinyMCE.
TinyMCE is easily integrated into your projects with the help of components such as:
tinymce-react
tinymce-vue
tinymce-angular
With over 29 integrations, and 400+ APIs, see the TinyMCE docs for a full list of editor integrations.

It is easy to configure the UI of your rich text editor to match the design of your site, product or application. Due to its flexibility, you can configure the editor with as much or as little functionality as you like, depending on your requirements.
With 30 powerful plugins available, and content editable as the basis of HugeRTE, adding additional functionality is as simple as including a single line of code.
Realizing the full power of most plugins requires only a few lines more.

Sometimes your editor requirements can be quite unique, and you need the freedom and flexibility to innovate. Thanks to HugeRTE being open source, you can view the source code and develop your own extensions for custom functionality to meet your own requirements.

The HugeRTE API is exposed to make it easier for you to write custom functionality that fits within the existing framework of HugeRTE UI components. Just don't forget to replace every instance of the tinymce object in the TinyMCE docs by hugerte.
In 2019 TinyMCE made the decision to transition their codebase to a monorepo. For information on compiling and contributing, see: contribution guidelines.
As an open source product, we encourage and support the active development of our software.
Visit the HugeRTE website and check out the TinyMCE documentation until we host the docs ourselves.

Removed InsertOrderedList and InsertUnorderedList from core. #TINY-10644
Removed closeButton from NotificationSpec, close button in notification is now rendered by default. #TINY-10646
The autocompleter ch configuration property has been removed. Use the trigger property instead. #TINY-8929
Adding newline after using selection.setContent to insert a block element would throw an unhandled exception. #TINY-10560
Autocomplete would sometimes cause corrupt data when starting during text composition. #TINY-10317
Directly right clicking on a ol's li in FireFox didn't enable the button List Properties... in the context menu. #TINY-10490
Fixed incorrect object processor for event_root option. #TINY-10433
Floating toolbar buttons in inline editor incorrectly wrapped into multiple rows on window resizing or zooming. #TINY-10570
Heading formatting would be partially applied to the content within the summary element when the caret was positioned between words. #TINY-10312
Inline mode with persisted toolbar would show regardless of the skin being loaded, causing css issues #TINY-10482
Moving focus to the outside of the editor after having clicked a menu would not fire a blur event as expected. #TINY-10310
Pressing Backspace at the start of an empty summary element within a details element nested in a list item no longer removes the summary element. #TINY-10303
Removed manually dispatching dragend event on drop in Firefox. #TINY-10389
Slovenian help dialog content had a dot in the wrong place. #TINY-10601
Table classes couldn't be removed via setting an empty value in table_class_list. Also fixed being forced to pick the first class option. #TINY-6653
The link_default_target option wasn't considered when inserting a link via quicklink toolbar. #TINY-10439
The toolbar width was miscalculated for the inline editor positioned inside a scrollable container. #TINY-10581
When deleting the last row in a table, the cursor would jump to the first cell (top left), instead of moving to the next adjacent cell in some cases. #TINY-6309
When inline editor toolbar wrapped to multiple lines the top wasn't always calculated correctly. #TINY-10580
When setting table border width and table_style_by_css is true, only the border attribute is set to 0 and border-width styling is no longer used #TINY-10308
For information about the available profiles and generating fixtures generation, read Generate data for performance testing.
node - most likely the latest stable one
KFD Theme Override for Snowdog Menu.
Accessed from admin > content > menus > kfd_header_menu

nodeclasses = I have tweaked this in a way, so that when you add an icon from the following * Icon Reference, it will append it to the before psuedo element of the a class. See templates/menu/node_type/categpry.phtml
*Icon Reference
Styles under styles > blocks > _ navigation.scss
node - most likely the latest stable one
Main menu must have directwatertanks_header_menu identifier and header-navigation class setup
First root node must have childrens, and it's link may not be visible everywhere - used as main menu list
Last root node may be cms block node and if it is it must have header-navigation__item--text class
nav-no-title- hides title of submenu container
nav-no-view-all- hides view all button from submenu
nav-icon-list- adds fa-bars icon to a link
nav-attractive- will make link color orangeish
nav-two-columns- will split list into two columns
Source: https://tabler.io/icons

To get detailed information about changes in Magento 2.3.0, see the Release Notes
To get detailed information about changes in Magento 2.2.0, see the Release Notes
To get detailed information about changes in Magento 2.1.0, please visit Magento Community Edition (CE) Release Notes
Eliminated multiple escaping in the inline translation pop-up
Fixed an issue where discount to the shipping amount was not applied during invoice creation
Fixed an issue where inline translations did not work correctly for phrases with special characters
Fixed an issue where it was impossible to create a credit memo for the order with downloadable product and sales rule applied
Fixed an issue where it was impossible to manually add products to a configurable product
Fixed an issue where it was impossible to register a customer on the storefront if an attribute with file type was required
Fixed an issue where Product API did not work properly for not default store code
Fixed an issue where searching in Billing Agreements grid in Admin resulted in an SQL
Fixed an issue where the category storefront URL did not include its parents
Fixed an issue where Totals were not calculated correctly if discount was applied when placing an order from Admin
Fixed an issue with custom timezone
Fixed bugs:
Fixed filtering by date in grids
Fixed filtering of online customers by session Start Time
Fixed issues with adding images for a first product in a new attribute set
Fixed the issues in the Custom Admin URL with https functionality
Fixed the Refresh Lifetime Statistics functionality in Reports
Increased the limit of cookies per domain, according to following recommendations https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6265#section-6.1
#2128-- wrong filename on products list
#2276-- Notice: getimagesize(): Read error! in app/code/Magento/Catalog/Model/Product/Image.php on line 949
Fixed a category page load time
Fixed an error which appeared during product import with replace behavior
Fixed an issue were URL rewrites in catalog categories were wrong after URL key for a store view was changed or a category was moved
Fixed an issue where 'Admin' was not a required field for the new Swatch
Fixed an issue where a bundle product created using Web API was not visible on the storefront
Fixed an issue where a user was redirected to a blank page when canceling checkout with PayPal Express in Website Payments Pro Hosted Solution
Fixed an issue where Admin panel was not accessible if port was used in URL
Fixed an issue where an error caused by adding a new swatch attribute persisted after deleting the attribute

PHP has had a built-in web sever since version 5.4.
PHP's web server provides a router script for use with server rewrites. Magento, like many other applications and frameworks, requires server rewrites. The router script either:
The web server executes the requested PHP script using a server-side include
Returns false, which means the web server returns the file using file system lookup
Example: requests to /static/frontend/Magento/blank/en_US/mage/calendar.css should deliver the file if it exists, or execute /static.php if not.
Without a router script, that is not possible via the php built-in server.
Please read how to install Magento using the command line. An example follows:

Note: By default, Magento creates a random Admin URI for you. Make sure to write this value down because it's how you access the Magento Admin later. For example: http://127.0.0.1:8082/index.php/admin_1vpn01.
For more information about the installation process using the CLI, you can consult the dedicated documentation that can found in the developer documentation.
Example usage:
The $debug option provides low-level logging for debugging purposes.
Forwarding rules:
Any request for favicon.ico or for any path that starts with index.php, get.php, static.php are processed normally.
Requests for the path pub/errors/default are rewritten as errors/default. This is provided for compatibility with older versions.

Files under request paths media, opt, or static are tested; if the file exists, the file is served. If the file does not exist, static files are forwarded to static.php and media files are forwarded to get.php((How about opt?))
If no rules are matched, return a 404 (Not Found).
Then rewrite paths for pub/errors/default/ by removing the pub/ part. (was at least needed for older versions)
Request starting with media/, opt/, static/ test if the file exists. If Yes, then handle it, if not "forward" static to static.php and media to get.php
If none of the rules matched, return 404. You may instead include the index.php, if 404 should be handled by Magento or you want urls without index.php/.

l: How to access to the admin dashboard
p: When the installation is finished, you can access Magento as follows:
Storefront: your Magento base URL
Magento Admin: your Magento base URL/admin URI
Magento values the contributions of the security research community, and we look forward to working with you to minimize risk to Magento merchants.

l: Where should I report security issues?
p: We strongly encourage you to report all security issues privately via our bug bounty program. Please provide us with relevant technical details and repro steps to expedite our investigation. If you prefer not to use HackerOne, email us directly at psirt@adobe.com with details and repro steps.
To learn more about securing a Magento store, please visit the Security Center.
Using Yoda conditions can prevent bugs from appearing on the live site, trading them for easy-to-resolve errors.
Yoda conditions reverse the order of the condition. Instead of writing:
you write:
Because if, for example, you accidentally miss the second =:
instead of constantly setting $input to 'yes' and causing a bug you have to troubleshoot, you will instead get an error you can easily correct at compilation time.
Program like Yoda.

This project is beeing deployed on AWS - London (region: eu-west-2)
Application Load Balancer (ALB)- distributes a traffic between multiple same instances serving same purpose. Used often with combination of autoscaling so it can handle bigger/lower demand.

Auto Scaling Group (AS/ASG)- a service that automatically creates/removes instances to match your desired number and to address temporary higher or lower usage of them. Creates inscances based on Lauch Template or Launch Configuration.
AWS
basic commands
Basic Linux
Before starting on this ensure you have knowledge of following
Cluster- A logic group of ECS instances
container lifecycle
difference between image and container
DNS SRV records
Docker
docker volumes
Dockerfile
EC2
ECR- an AWS managed Docker registry allowing us to upload our docker images. Our private Docker Hub
ECS
ECS Instance- an EC2 instance that has Docker installed and runs ECS container agent. It belongs to one cluster and it's able to run tasks
Elastic File Storage (EFS)- an AWS network drive.
environment variables
HTTP / HTTPS

Launch Template / Launch Configuration- a description of how EC2 instance should be configured. Type, size, network, etc... It also includes userdata field where you can put your script to run when EC2 instance starts. Only Launch Configuration in past was for Autoscaling, now both can be used
Networking
ports
registry

Security groups (SG)- firewall in short. Describes what ports and ip can be accessed. SG is can be attached to many things in AWS. Such as EC2, ALB, RDS, EFS, ElastiCache etc - all that can handle any network traffic at all
Service- Long running tasks of the specified task definition. This can be any number (0..n) tasks running same task definition. Can be updated to use newer or different version of task definition
shell scripts
Systems Manager (SSM) - Parameter Store- a place where we can safely store parameters (such as database host, username, password). Those parameters can be then used in Task Definition.
Target Group (TG)- a group of services (for exampe EC2) that can are used in ALB. ALB can switch quickly between multiple Target groups allowing quick seamless deployments.
Task Definition- A file which is used to tell Cluster and ECS Instance how to run Docker container(s)
Task- A running container with the settings defined in task definition. In other words instance of Task definition
what problems it solves
This applies to both test and production setups. Further down there is more detailed information about each specific environment.

This is one time setup. Clusters should be used for more than just one project. I missed that knowledge, but we're heading that way. And at the moment it is setup, but it will be good for you to know how to set it up.
Create ECS Cluster. This also creates following resources:
Auto Scaling Group
Lauch Configuration
Update Auto Scaling group
Convert Launch Configuration to Launch Template (easier to manage)
Update ASG to use our new Launch Template
Create EFS for media storage. Using SG allow only ECS Instances to access it
Update Launch Template, so:
It mounts an media EFS so it can be accessed
Installs awscli command (it's usefull)
(To be changed) Create a script that will upload backups created by tasks to S3
The cluster should be now ready to use.
As AWS offers RDS - Database service we'll create a MySQL server there, and let them manage it.
Same applies for Redis offered from ElastiCache server.
As we have now cluster we need to setup the project so it can run on the cluser. To do that in short we'll need to understand a nature of the project.
Magento as a website will need to run on a configured web server. In our case we use nginx software backed up by php.
Apart from that Magento runs several tasks in background. For that it uses cron software.

Based on that knowledge we'll need to create 2 task definitions. One for webserver, which will run 2 connected docker containers (nginx + php) And other for cron which will run one docker container (php).
Based on knowledge from previous paragraph we need to create our docker images. Before we do that though we need Magento code to put in the images.
Code is created on first few steps of Bitbucket Pipeline. In short it does:
Installs composer depenedncies
Prepares theme(s)
Install npm dependencies
Compiles styles fonts etc.
Runs magento command to compile DI files and deploy static files
Result files will be available for later steps in pipeline (described later)
As we understand how Magento works we realised 2 docker images will be needed.
They're created in next pipeline steps using the repository code + the one created in previous steps.
The result images are uploaded to ECR with appropriate names.

This image is simple as it should contain only nginx configuration and Magento public assets (as they don't need php for processing). PHP file requests will be passed to php, so that files are not needed here.
The Dockerfile is quite simple and all it really does:
Extends default nginx image
Copies nginx configurations
Copies over public files to appripriate location
php image will contain all compiled magento code, php + configuration and optionally run cron service.
Dockerfile is more complex than nginx, and depends on our other project, which configures generic Magento 2 PHP image with required extensions - docker-magento2-php
Please have look on that other project as it's essential to our setup. Here is a little of a summary:
Installs php and required extensions
Puts php.ini values recommended by Magento
Installs composer
Adds scripts to allow us configure Magento env.php (database, cache, and few other bits)
The docker file from this repository adds the project code on top of that.
At this point we have our Docker images with compiled Magento in ECR.
Further pipeline steps are creating task definition based on a template files.
There is no point of me describing all parameters from there. For that please refeer to AWS Task Definition Parameters Documentation.
Few of the values are a `` which are replaced with a script. Those values differ based on environment we deploy to. Values are configured somewhere within Bitbucker Pipeline or Settings.
The script will also push the task definitions to ECS.

Note on env variables: docker-magento2-php project mentions environment variables that need to be present in order to sucessfully start this container. Those values should be saved in SSM Parameter Storage and are already referenced in task definition templates._

Note on ports: Internally nginx docker image exposes port 8080. Task definition is set to forward this port to the port 0 on host (ECS Instance). That means docker will find any available port on host and assign it to it. That's not a problem as the webserver is behind load balancer, which is available to ports 80 and 443 to customers and it just connects internally to ECS Task on different ports.
We have now all we needed prepared. Last step is to run docker images.

When you run/update ECS service you'll approach multiple questions and based on the environment it differs. That will be described later per environment, but there are few important things to know now:
Service uses task definition to start new tasks.
You can decide how many "copies" of the tasks you want.
You can setup a Load Balancer for your tasks.
You can setup a DNS SRV records.
In general the services should be already there and configured and your task will be mostly to update them to use newer task definition.
Production revolves around the master branch, when a feature or fix branch is merged into master.
Docker images created are tagged as follows to avoid conflicts and keep older images in case we need to rollback.
kingfisherdirect/kfd-magento-php:release-{commit}
kingfisherdirect/kfd-magento-nginx:release-{commit}
For production we use Redis and it's parameters are stored in SSM prod/magento/redis/..., which are passed in Task Definition to Magento setup script.
Task definition will use parameters from SSM Parameters Store with the prefix/prod/magento/...
The pipeline sets an environment variable ( MAGE_DEPLOY__SKIP_SETUP) preventing [docker-magento2-php]( Dockerfile entrypoint script from running and complaining about need of setup:upgrade
Task definition names are as follows:
magento-webserver_prod
magento-cli_prod
magento-cron_prod
ECS service is setup with load balancer which is connected to our domain.
It also uses blue/green deployment to avoid downtimes during deployment.

Using blue/green deployment allows us also run Lambda function just after new task is created, but before traffic is redirected to it. This allows us to run Lambda function, that runs bin/magento setup:upgrade using not mentioned previously cli task definition (PHP but able to run bin/magento command, not as different).

Once setup is done b/g deployment runs health checks on new task and if all good it replaces ALB to use new task group (which contains new task). It keeps also old task in old task group for an hour in case new one will start playing up.

This setup is not perfect and may cause problems with rollbacks, but that's to sort out later. Because of this its RECOMMENDED to update service during less busy periods - especiall if any of module is added, updated or removed.
Apart from what has been said above the load balancer is also configured with SSL certificate and redirects all traffic to HTTPS.
Development revolves around feature& fix branches, when a pull request is created.
We have 4 test places where you can deploy your changes.
Default: [WEBSITE].mage.dev.kingfisherdirect.co.uk
Echo: [WEBSITE].echo.mage.dev.kingfisherdirect.co.uk
Golf: [WEBSITE].golf.mage.dev.kingfisherdirect.co.uk
Lima: [WEBSITE].lima.mage.dev.kingfisherdirect.co.uk
All of them are using Load Balancer. Custom one, not the AWS as we don't want to spend too much money on them.
HAProxy LB is setup on Bastion server and its status can be seen on https://mage.dev.kingfisherdirect.co.uk/hpx?statistics
All you need to know on this is that it uses DNS SRV entries to resolve into[HOST]:[PORT] which it uses internally to to serve page.
Docker images tags:
kingfisherdirect/kfd-magento-php:{branch-name}
kingfisherdirect/kfd-magento-nginx:{branch-name}
Task definition names are as follows:
magento-webserver_{branch-name}_{environment}
magento-cli_{branch-name}_{environment}
magento-cron_{branch-name}_{environment}
Environment depends on where you want to deploy your changes and may be one of test, test-echo, test-golf and test-lima.
Each environment will also have it's own set of SSM parameters with prefix beeing one of test, test-echo, test-golf and test-lima.
No blue/green deployment here.
Each task creates an autodiscovery DNS SRV entry, to be used with HaProxy LB.
Again same as on production, you don't need to create a service - just update.
There is a script on bastion called clone-db.sh.
It will import last backup into DB of specified test server.
Usage: clone-db.sh [TARGET], where [TARGET] is one of default, echo, golf, lima.
During script execution it will ask you about DB password. Command to get it from AWS is provided by a script - just run it from your computer.
After DB is imported few changes must be done to database. Log in into appropriate EC2 Instance which runs the docker task for your environment, and run provided commands on PHP container.

Client Forks: clientname/odb- One per client that needs variation

For each client fork:

Protect main from direct pushes

Or using rebase (cleaner history):

l: ODB Fork Model: Explanation and Implementation

p: Move from client-specific branches to separate fork repositories for client customizations of ODB.
Current State:
ODB installed via Composer
Client customizations done as branches in the main ODB repo
All branches in one repository ( rxmodules-development/odb)
Desired State:
Each client has their own repository
Client-specific code isolated from main ODB
Easier to manage client-specific changes
Clear separation of concerns
GitHub's "Fork" button creates a UI relationship between repositories:
Shows "forked from..." in the repository UI
Enables easy pull requests back to the original
Limitation: Cannot fork within the same organization
Why this matters:
We typically work within rixxo-devops organization
We don't put repositories in client organizations
Therefore, GitHub's native fork feature cannot be used
We've created separate repositories with manual upstream configuration:
Each client repository has:
origin remote → points to itself
upstream remote → points to rixxo-devops/ODB
Syncing from upstream (same as forking):
Making client-specific changes:
Pulling generic improvements from upstream:

l: Why This Achieves the Same Thing
p: GitHub Native Fork
Our Manual Fork Model
Shows "forked from" in UI
No UI indicator (but functionally identical)
Can create PRs to upstream
Can create PRs to upstream (same org)
Automatic upstream tracking
Manual upstream remote (same result)
Can't fork same org
Works within same org ✅
Requires separate org
Works in our org ✅
Key Point: The workflow is identical. The only difference is the GitHub UI doesn't show the fork relationship, but all the functionality works the same.

l: If We Want True GitHub Forks

p: To use GitHub's native fork feature, we would need to:
Host forks in client organizations(not rixxo-devops)
Each client would need their own GitHub organization
We'd fork rixxo-devops/ODB→ client-org/ODB
Example:

l: Why This Typically Doesn't Work for Us
p: Client organizations don't exist:
Clients don't have GitHub organizations
We don't want to create/manage client GitHub accounts
Clients don't need direct GitHub access
Composer installation:
ODB is installed via Composer in client projects
Composer pulls from repositories
Having repos in client orgs would require:
Managing client GitHub credentials
Setting up authentication for each client
More complex deployment process
Our workflow:
We maintain all code in rixxo-devops
We control access and permissions
We don't want to distribute repos across multiple organizations
All repos in rixxo-devops
No need for client organizations
Centralized management
Can sync from upstream
Can merge upstream changes
Can create PRs (within same org)
Isolated client code
Clear separation per client
No branch clutter in main repo
Easier to manage client-specific code
Can set different permissions per client repo
Can still install via Composer
Points to rixxo-devops/ODB or client-specific repo
No authentication complexity

l: Comparison: Branches vs Our Fork Model vs True Forks
p: ⚠️ (more complex)
Branches (Old)
Centralized management
Client org required
Code isolation
Composer friendly
Feature
Manual
Manual (same)
Our Fork Model
Same organization
Sync from upstream
True GitHub Forks
UI fork indicator
Our manual fork model achieves the same goals as GitHub forking:
✅ Isolated client repositories
✅ Ability to sync from upstream
✅ Clear separation of concerns
✅ Works within our organization
✅ Compatible with our workflow
The only difference: GitHub's UI doesn't show a "forked from" indicator, but functionally it works identically.
If we want true GitHub forks: We'd need to host repositories in client organizations, which doesn't fit our typical workflow and Composer-based installation process.
Stick with our manual fork model because:
It achieves all the same goals
Works within our organization
Compatible with Composer
Easier to manage centrally
No need for client GitHub organizations
The lack of a GitHub UI fork indicator is a minor cosmetic difference that doesn't affect functionality.

These errors are NOT related to cron jobs. They're frontend JavaScript issues with your checkout process.
What it means:
This is a React/WordPress Block Editor (Gutenberg) issue
The checkout block is returning inconsistent validation states
Usually a plugin or theme conflict
Solutions:
Temporarily deactivate plugins one by one, especially:
Payment gateway plugins (2Checkout, WooCommerce extensions)
Checkout optimization plugins
Cart/checkout customizers
Test checkout after each deactivation
Temporarily switch to a default WordPress theme (Twenty Twenty-Four)
Test if checkout works
If it works, your theme has a conflict
Clear WordPress cache (if using caching plugin)
Clear browser cache
Clear CDN cache (if using Cloudflare, clear cache there)
Update WordPress core
Update WooCommerce
Update all plugins
Update your theme
Go to WooCommerce→ Status→ Tools
Click Clear transients
Click Clear template cache
What it means:
The 2Checkout payment gateway extension is having issues
Browser extension conflict or payment gateway script error
Communication between your site and 2Checkout is failing
Solutions:
Disable all browser extensions(especially ad blockers, privacy tools)
Try in incognito/private mode
Try a different browser
Go to WooCommerce→ Settings→ Payments
Find 2Checkout payment method
Verify API credentials are correct
Check if test mode is enabled (might cause issues)
Go to Plugins→ Installed Plugins
Find your 2Checkout plugin
Deactivate and reactivate it
Check for plugin updates
Go to WooCommerce→ Status→ Logs
Look for errors related to:
2checkout
payment
checkout
Share any errors you find
Temporarily enable a different payment method (like PayPal or bank transfer)
Test checkout - if it works, the issue is specifically with 2Checkout
This helps isolate the problem

l: 6. Check JavaScript Console for More Errors
p: Open browser Developer Tools (F12)
Go to Console tab
Look for additional errors when clicking checkout
Note any red error messages
Add to wp-config.php(via RunCloud file manager or SSH):
Then check /wp-content/debug.log for errors.
In RunCloud:
Go to your server
Check Logs section
Look for PHP errors or Apache/Nginx errors
Check around the time you tried to place an order

l: 3. Test Checkout Process Step by Step
p: Add product to cart
Go to checkout page
Fill in billing details
Fill in shipping details
Select payment method
Click "Place Order"
Note at which step the error appears.
In browser Developer Tools:
Go to Network tab
Try to place an order
Look for failed requests (red entries)
Check the Response for failed requests
Look for requests to 2checkout or checkout endpoints
Clear all caches (WordPress, browser, CDN)
Disable browser extensions and test
Test in incognito mode
Deactivate plugins one by one to find conflict
Switch to default theme temporarily
Update WordPress, WooCommerce, and all plugins
Check 2Checkout plugin settings and credentials
Check WooCommerce logs for errors
Enable WordPress debugging and check debug.log
Test with different payment method
Browser Extension Conflict(especially ad blockers)
Outdated Plugin/Theme(2Checkout plugin or WooCommerce)
Plugin Conflict(another plugin interfering with checkout)
Theme Conflict(theme JavaScript conflicting with checkout)
Caching Issues(cached JavaScript causing problems)
Contact 2Checkout Support:
They may have known issues or updates
Provide them with the error message
Check WooCommerce Support Forums:
Search for similar issues
Post your error details
Consider Alternative Payment Gateway:
Temporarily use PayPal or Stripe
This confirms if it's a 2Checkout-specific issue
✅ These errors are NOT related to cron jobs
✅ These are frontend JavaScript/React issues
✅ Your cron job setup is separate from this problem
✅ Fixing these won't affect your cron job
The cron job you set up is for WordPress scheduled tasks (like publishing posts, updates, etc.). These checkout errors are completely separate frontend issues.

l: How to Find Your WordPress Site's Hosting Provider
p: Since someone else set up your WordPress site, here are several methods to identify where it's hosted:

l: ⚠️ IMPORTANT: If You See Cloudflare Nameservers
p: If your nameservers show *.ns.cloudflare.com(like lily.ns.cloudflare.com), Cloudflare is proxying your site. The actual hosting is behind Cloudflare. You need to find the origin server.

l: Quick Steps to Find Origin IP (Try These First)
p: Check Cloudflare Dashboard(BEST METHOD):
Go to: https://dash.cloudflare.com/
Log in (try password reset if needed)
Select your domain
Go to DNS→ Records
Find the A record for your domain (or @ record)
The IP address shown is your origin server IP
Note: If the cloud icon is orange (proxied), you'll see Cloudflare IPs. Temporarily turn off proxy (gray cloud) to see real IP, or check the IP that was there before proxy was enabled.
Command Line Method(if you have terminal access):
Check ManageWP for Server Info:
ManageWP may show the actual server IP in site details
Check Server Info or Site Information sections

l: Finding the Origin Server Behind Cloudflare
p: Check Cloudflare Dashboard(if you have access):
Check Email/Setup Records:
Check for server IP addresses in old emails
Check Historical DNS records - may show the origin IP before Cloudflare was added
Check Historical DNS Records:
Check WordPress wp-config.php(if accessible):
Database host in wp-config.php often shows the server
Enter your domain
Find Origin IP via DNS Lookup(Cloudflare proxy disabled):
Go to DNS settings
Log into Cloudflare: https://dash.cloudflare.com/
Look at the A record- it should show the origin IP address
Look for DB_HOST- may contain server IP or hostname
Look for initial setup emails from DigitalOcean
Look for SSH connection details in documentation
Look for the A record IP address
Note: If Cloudflare proxy is ON (orange cloud), you'll see Cloudflare IPs, not the origin
Select your domain
The IP address is your actual server (likely DigitalOcean droplet)
Visit: https://mxtoolbox.com/DNSLookup.aspx
Visit: https://securitytrails.com/
You may need to temporarily disable Cloudflare proxy to see the real IP
Ask the person who set it up about team access
Check all projects/teams you have access to
Check DigitalOcean Email:
Check if you're invited to any DigitalOcean teams
Check Team/Organization Access:
Contact DigitalOcean Support:
If you have the IP address, contact DigitalOcean support
In DigitalOcean dashboard, look for droplets
Log into DigitalOcean:
Look for setup emails, invoices, or notifications
Once you have the IP address:
Provide the IP and domain name
Search by IP Address:
Search or filter by the IP address you found
Search your email for "DigitalOcean" or "droplet"
The droplet might be in a team/organization account
These often contain droplet names and IPs
They can help identify which account owns the droplet
Try logging in with emails associated with the project
Use "Forgot Password" if needed
Visit: https://cloud.digitalocean.com/
You may need to prove ownership of the domain
If you have access to ManageWP:
Log into your ManageWP account
Click on the WordPress site in question
Look for:
Server Info or Hosting Details section
Site Info tab - may show hosting provider
Backups section - backup storage location often indicates host
Performance or Uptime sections - may show server details

l: Method 2: Use Online Hosting Checker Tools
p: These tools can identify the hosting provider by analyzing your website:
Web Hosting Checker
Visit: https://www.webhostingchecker.com/
Enter your website URL
View hosting provider and server location
WhoIsHostingThis
Visit: https://www.whoishostingthis.com/
Enter your domain name
Shows hosting provider and IP address
BuiltWith
Visit: https://builtwith.com/
Shows hosting provider and technology stack
ICANN WHOIS Lookup
Visit: https://lookup.icann.org/
Enter your domain name
Check the Name Servers section
Name servers often indicate the hosting provider:
ns1.hostgator.com= HostGator
ns1.bluehost.com= Bluehost
ns1.siteground.com= SiteGround
ns1.wpengine.com= WP Engine
ns1.godaddy.com= GoDaddy
etc.
Alternative WHOIS Tools
https://whois.net/
https://www.whois.com/
Online Header Checkers
Visit: https://www.whatsmyip.org/http-headers/
Enter your website URL
Look for headers like:
Server:- may show web server type
X-Powered-By:- may show hosting info
X-Host: or X-Served-By:- often shows hosting provider
Browser Developer Tools
Open your website in Chrome/Firefox

Order Status Mapping synchronizes order statuses between OrderWise and Shopify. This allows Shopify orders to update to reflect their current status in OrderWise (Fulfilled, Cancelled, or Refunded).
OrderWise Statuses→ Shopify Statuses
Supported Shopify Statuses: Fulfilled, Cancelled, Refunded
Automatic Updates: ShopWise checks OrderWise every 15 minutes for status changes
Bidirectional Sync: Status changes in OrderWise update Shopify orders
Before setting up status mapping, you need to create an OrderWise API Export Definition.

l: Step 1: Create OrderWise API Export Definition
p: Open OrderWise
Click E-Commerce(bottom-left menu)
Click API Export Definitions(top-left menu)
API Export Definitions
Click Add
Give it a clear name, e.g., ShopWise Status Sync
Status Export Definition
In the SQL Statement box, paste the following:

l: Step 2: Get the Export Definition ID
p: In API Export Definitions, right-click the grid and choose Edit Grid Layout
Edit Grid Layout
Add Export Definition ID to the grid
Add Export ID
Save and note the Export Definition ID for your status export
In Shopify, open ShopWise → Configuration → Status Mapping
Status Mapping Interface
Enter the Export Definition ID you just found
ShopWise will now check OrderWise every 15 minutes for status updates

l: Step 3: Map OrderWise Statuses to Shopify
p: Map your OrderWise statuses to the three supported Shopify statuses:
Fulfilled
Enter the exact OrderWise status text that indicates fulfillment
Example: "Dispatched", "Shipped", "Delivered"
Cancelled
Enter the exact OrderWise status text that indicates cancellation
Example: "Cancelled", "Void", "Abandoned"
Refunded
Enter the exact OrderWise status text that indicates refund
Example: "Refunded", "Returned", "Credit Note"
Click Save to apply the mappings
The export definition returns data in this format:
orderNumber: Must be the OrderWise internal order ID ( oh_id)
orderStatus: Human-readable status from OrderWise
Do not change field names or structure in the SQL
Default: 1 hour ( DATEADD(HOUR, -1, GETDATE()))
Adjustment: Change the hour value as needed
Recommendation: Keep ≥ 15 minutes to match ShopWise polling frequency
Exact Match Required: OrderWise status text must match exactly
Case Sensitive: Include proper capitalization
Spacing: Include exact spacing and punctuation
Check Export Data: Run the SQL query directly in OrderWise
Verify Order Numbers: Ensure orderNumber field contains OrderWise oh_id
Test Status Changes: Change an order status in OrderWise
Monitor Shopify: Check if the Shopify order updates within 15 minutes
Review Logs: Check ShopWise logs for any sync errors
Status Updates Not Appearing
Verify Export Definition ID is correct
Check that export returns results for the current time window
Ensure OrderWise status text matches exactly (including spacing/capitalization)
Wrong Status Mapping
Double-check status text spelling and format
Verify the status exists in OrderWise
Check for duplicate or conflicting mappings
Orders Not Found
Ensure orderNumber field maps to OrderWise oh_id
Verify the order exists in both systems
Check that the order was originally created by ShopWise
Check Export Definition: Verify the SQL query returns expected data
Monitor Logs: Review ShopWise logs for error messages
Test Time Window: Ensure the time window includes recent changes
Verify Mappings: Double-check status text matches exactly
Large Datasets: Consider filtering by order status or date ranges
Frequent Updates: Adjust time window based on your update frequency
Database Load: Monitor OrderWise performance during exports
Use consistent status naming in OrderWise
Document all status mappings for reference
Test status changes before going live
Review mappings when adding new order statuses
Update mappings if OrderWise status names change
Monitor integration performance regularly
With status mapping configured:
Product Updates- Set up product data synchronization
Troubleshooting- Test the complete integration
Log Manager- Monitor integration health
Status mapping complete? Proceed to Product Updates to configure product data synchronization.

This section covers the main configuration settings for connecting your Shopify store with OrderWise. The integration includes four key areas: Basic Settings, Payment Mappings, Shipping Mappings, and Status Mappings.
Integration Sections
Basic settings control the core functionality required for the OrderWise app to operate correctly.
The OrderWise base URL is the API endpoint for your OrderWise instance. This is where all data will be sent.
Format: https://your-orderwise-instance.com/api/
This is a base64-encoded version of user credentials for OrderWise authentication.
How to create credentials:
Take your username and password
Format as: username:password
Encode using base64 encryption
Use online tools like base64encode.org or AI services like ChatGPT
Example:
Username: rabbit
Password: carrot
Format: rabbit:carrot
Base64 encoded: cmFiYml0OmNhcnJvdA==
Credential Hash
The Session ID is the OrderWise e-commerce session ID that orders will be sent through.
To find your Session ID:
Go to your OrderWise instance
Click E-Commerce in the bottom left menu
Click E-Commerce Sessions in the top left menu
Identify your import session
Right-click and select Edit Grid Layout
Add the ID column to see the Session ID
Session ID Location
This setting allows you to specify a default stock location for all orders from this store.
Must match your stock location ID in OrderWise
Optional setting - leave blank if not needed
Ensures consistent stock location assignment
This is the customer ID that all orders will be placed against in OrderWise.
To find a Customer ID:
Go to your customers in OrderWise
Right-click on the screen and select Edit Grid Layout
Add the Customer ID column
Note the ID of the customer you want to use
Customer ID
This field is for notifications of failed orders. Any email addresses entered here will receive notifications when order synchronization fails.
Recommended: Use a monitored email address for your integration team.
Once you've configured all basic settings, your integration should include:
✅ OrderWise Base URL
✅ Credential Hash (base64 encoded)
✅ Session ID from your e-commerce session
✅ Stock Location ID (if applicable)
✅ Customer ID for orders
✅ Notification email address
With basic settings configured, you can now set up:
Stock Updates- Configure inventory synchronization
Payment Mapping- Map Shopify payment methods to OrderWise
Shipping Mapping- Map shipping methods between systems
Status Mapping- Configure order status synchronization
After setting up basic settings:
Check the Log Manager for any connection errors
Try sending a test order from Shopify
Verify the order appears in OrderWise
Check that notifications are working
Basic settings configured? Proceed to Stock Updates to set up inventory synchronization.
Payment mapping allows you to map Shopify payment methods to corresponding OrderWise payment method IDs. This ensures orders are processed with the correct payment information in OrderWise.
Payment Mapping Interface
Shopify Payment Methods→ OrderWise Payment IDs
Automatic Mapping: Orders use the mapped payment method when sent to OrderWise
Flexible Configuration: Add new payment methods as needed
Gateway Matching: Uses Shopify's gateway ID for accurate identification
Payment Exclusion: Option to exclude payment information from OrderWise order payload for specific payment methods
To map payment methods, you need the payment method IDs from OrderWise:
Log in to OrderWise
Click System in the bottom left menu
Navigate to Sales Order → Payment Methods in the top left menu
Right-click on the screen and select Edit Grid Layout
Add the ID column to the grid
Note the IDs for each payment method you want to map
OrderWise Payment Methods
In ShopWise, go to Configuration → Payment Mappings
Click Add new payment gateway in the top right
Add Payment Gateway
You'll be asked to provide:
1. Payment Gateway
This is the display name for the payment gateway
Used as the admin label in ShopWise
Example: "Credit Card", "PayPal", "Bank Transfer"
2. Gateway ID
This is the ID that Shopify uses for the gateway
Must match exactly or the mapping won't work
Found in Shopify's payment settings or order data
Enter the OrderWise Payment Method ID from the previous step
Exclude from OrderWise Order Payload(Optional):
Tick this box if you want to exclude payment information from the OrderWise order payload for this specific payment method
This is useful for payment methods that don't need to be sent to OrderWise (e.g., external payment processors that handle payment separately)
When ticked, the payment details will not be included when the order is sent to OrderWise
Click Save to apply the mapping
Gateway ID: Usually credit_card or specific processor name
OrderWise ID: Your credit card payment method ID
Gateway ID: paypal or paypal_express
OrderWise ID: Your PayPal payment method ID
Gateway ID: bank_transfer or manual
OrderWise ID: Your bank transfer payment method ID
Gateway ID: cod or cash_on_delivery
OrderWise ID: Your COD payment method ID
To find the exact Gateway ID that Shopify uses:
Go to Settings → Payments in Shopify admin
Check the payment provider settings
Look at order details in Shopify to see the gateway used
Use Shopify's API or admin interface to get exact gateway names

l: Excluding Payments from OrderWise Order Payload
p: For certain payment methods, you may want to exclude payment information from being sent to OrderWise in the order payload. This is useful for:
External payment processors that handle payment separately
Payment methods that don't require payment tracking in OrderWise
Third-party integrations where payment is managed outside OrderWise

l: How to Exclude a Payment Method
p: When configuring a payment method mapping, locate the Exclude from OrderWise Order Payload checkbox
Tick the box to exclude payment information for this payment method
Save the configuration
Note: When excluded, the payment details will not be included in the order payload sent to OrderWise, but the order itself will still be created.
Create Test Order: Place a test order in Shopify with each payment method
Check OrderWise: Verify the order appears with the correct payment method
Review Logs: Check ShopWise logs for any mapping errors
Test Edge Cases: Try orders with unmapped payment methods
Payment Method Not Mapped
Check that Gateway ID matches exactly (case-sensitive)
Verify OrderWise Payment ID is correct
Ensure the payment method exists in OrderWise
Orders Using Wrong Payment Method
Double-check Gateway ID spelling and format
Verify OrderWise Payment ID corresponds to the intended method
Check for duplicate or conflicting mappings
Use clear, descriptive names for payment gateways
Include the payment provider name when applicable
Avoid special characters or spaces in Gateway IDs
Keep a record of all payment method mappings
Document any special configurations or requirements
Note any payment methods that don't need mapping
Review mappings when adding new payment methods
Update mappings if payment providers change
Test mappings after any OrderWise configuration changes
With payment mapping configured:
Shipping Mapping- Set up shipping method mapping
Status Mapping- Configure order status synchronization
Product Updates- Set up product data synchronization
Payment mapping complete? Proceed to Shipping Mapping to configure shipping method mapping.

Product Updates & Mapping synchronizes product data between OrderWise and Shopify. This feature allows you to keep product information, pricing, and attributes synchronized across both systems using customizable field mappings.
OrderWise Products→ Shopify Variants
SKU Matching: Products are matched by variant code (SKU)
Field Mapping: Map OrderWise fields to Shopify metafields
Automatic Updates: ShopWise checks for product changes every 15 minutes
Flexible Configuration: Add custom fields as needed
Before setting up product updates, you need to create an OrderWise API Export Definition.

l: Step 1: Create OrderWise API Export Definition
p: Open OrderWise
Click E-Commerce(bottom-left menu)
Click API Export Definitions(top-left menu)
API Export Definitions
Click Add
Name it clearly, e.g., ShopWise Product Sync
Product Export Definition
In SQL Statement, paste this example (15-minute window):

l: Step 2: Get the Export Definition ID
p: In API Export Definitions, right-click the grid and choose Edit Grid Layout
Edit Grid Layout
Add Export Definition ID to the grid
Add Export ID
Save and note the Export Definition ID for your product export
In Shopify, open ShopWise → Configuration → Product Mapping
Product Mapping Interface
Enter the Product Export Definition ID from OrderWise
Configure field mappings to Shopify metafields
The export definition returns data in this format:
SKU Field
Must remain as sku- Do not change this field name
Purpose: Used to match Shopify variants
Source: OrderWise variant_code
Product Information
name→ Product title or description metafield
brand→ Brand metafield
weight→ Weight metafield
length, height, width→ Dimensions metafields
Pricing Information
regularPrice→ Price metafield
taxRateId→ Tax rate metafield
Compliance Fields
commodityCode→ HS code metafield
countryCodeOfOrigin→ Country of origin metafield

l: Step 1: Add Field to Export Definition
p: Edit your OrderWise export definition SQL
Add the new field to the SELECT statement
Use a clear alias name for the field
Go to Configuration → Product Mapping
Add a new mapping for your field
Specify the Shopify metafield namespace and key
Save the configuration
Shopify metafields use this structure:
Namespace: Grouping identifier (e.g., "custom", "product")
Key: Specific field identifier (e.g., "brand", "weight")
Type: Data type (text, number, boolean, etc.)
Time Window: 15 minutes ( DATEADD(MINUTE, -15, GETDATE()))
Polling Frequency: ShopWise checks every 15 minutes
Recommendation: Keep window ≥ 15 minutes to avoid missing updates
Check Export Data: Run the SQL query directly in OrderWise
Verify SKUs: Ensure OrderWise variant codes match Shopify SKUs
Test Field Updates: Change a product field in OrderWise
Monitor Shopify: Check if the Shopify product updates within 15 minutes
Review Logs: Check ShopWise logs for any sync errors
Products Not Updating
Verify Export Definition ID is correct
Check that export returns data for recent changes
Ensure SKU matches exactly between systems
Field Mapping Errors
Verify metafield namespace and key are correct
Check that metafields exist in Shopify
Ensure data types are compatible
Performance Issues
Consider filtering by product categories
Adjust time window based on update frequency
Monitor OrderWise database performance
You may want to filter products by specific criteria:
SQL Knowledge: Adding custom fields requires SQL editing skills
OrderWise Structure: Understanding of OrderWise database schema
Testing: Always test custom queries before deploying
Use consistent field naming conventions
Document all custom field mappings
Test field updates before going live
Filter by changed products only (as shown in SQL)
Consider product categories or warehouses for large datasets
Monitor export performance in OrderWise
Review mappings when adding new product fields
Update mappings if OrderWise structure changes
Monitor integration performance regularly
With product updates configured:
Troubleshooting- Test the complete integration
Log Manager- Monitor integration health
Go Live- Deploy your integration to production
Product updates configured? Proceed to Troubleshooting to test your complete integration.

Text-only buttons with underline follow same color rules
Highlight up to 3 words per line in Rixxo Green (#33CC99)
Use patterns like 2-1-2, 3-1-3, or 2-3 for visual balance
Only highlight if core message is clear from highlighted words alone
Never use colors other than Rixxo Green for highlighting
Short, fragment-style headings:
No punctuation (except question marks)
Cleaner design, more impact
Headlines with 5+ words:
Use punctuation intentionally for clarity
Marketing-style dual sentences:
Use punctuation (e.g., "Connect Orderwise. Automate the rest.")
Emphasizes rhythm and brand tone
Use sparingly for clarity
Reserved for breaking down sub-points within a single idea
Use separate lines for separate ideas
Never use full stops in bullet points
Never center-align bullet points
Always left-align
Minimalist: Every word has a reason to be there
Confident: No hedging, clear statements
Collaborative: "We" language, team-focused
Progressive: Always moving forward, always refining
Speak like a mentor, not an influencer
Direct, grounded, and practical
No ego, no performance
Focus on outcomes, not features
Use plain English, avoid jargon
Get straight to the point
Document Templates: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1tgvo_eMDA582UwP6Y_aUe8MxwIYGj4XTb7EGikzoqKs/edit?tab=t.0#heading=h.9q93aj50zhs1
Google Fonts:
Poppins: https://fonts.google.com/specimen/Poppins
Roboto: https://fonts.google.com/specimen/Roboto
Material Icons (Rounded, 40px, Green): https://fonts.google.com/icons?icon.set=Material+Icons&icon.style=Rounded&icon.size=40&icon.color=%2333cc99

This guide will help you create a fresh e-commerce session in OrderWise for your Shopify integration. Creating a new session avoids legacy quirks and ensures optimal order synchronization.
Ensure you have:
Admin access to OrderWise
Email address of the person responsible for the integration
A dedicated Shopify "admin user" in OrderWise for imported orders
Go to E-Commerce → E-Commerce Sessions in OrderWise
Click Add to create a new session
Name: Use something clear (e.g., your Shopify shop name)
Export: Set to Off(unticked)
Schedule: Set to Every 5 minutes
Notification email: Enter the responsible person's email
Session Creation
Why these settings?
Export off prevents unintended pushes
Short schedule keeps imports flowing
Notifications ensure someone sees errors promptly
Session Settings
Transfer Type: Set to Web Service
Review other options carefully—changes here can impact the integration
Import Setup
Note: Only change options you understand or that are documented by your integration plan.
Review all settings and confirm they fit your site's behavior:
Import orders as: Set a dedicated Shopify user(recommended)
Create a user in OrderWise for Shopify orders (e.g., Shopify_Orders)
This keeps audit trails tidy and avoids orders showing against real staff members
General Settings
Use Delivery Method system tax code: Ticked
Use CVariant system tax code: Ticked
Add Customer Contact to existing customer if not found: Ticked
Use CVariant stock location if default is not available: Ticked
Override Variant Disallow setting: Ticked
Tick all options(ensures stricter checks to maintain data quality)
Advanced Settings
Click Save to commit all settings.
After creating and saving your session, you'll need the Session ID for the Shopwise configuration:
Go to E-Commerce → E-Commerce Sessions
Identify your new import session
Right-click on the grid and select Edit Grid Layout
Add the ID column to the grid
Note the Session ID for use in Shopwise
Session ID
With your OrderWise session configured, you're ready to:
Configure Orderwise Integration- Set up the main integration settings
Set up Stock Updates- Configure inventory synchronization
Configure Mappings- Set up payment, shipping, and status mappings
Session created successfully? Proceed to Orderwise Integration to configure the main settings.

l: Setting Up Proper WordPress Cron Job in RunCloud
p: WordPress's default WP-Cron runs on page visits, which is unreliable. Setting up a proper system cron job ensures your scheduled tasks run on time.
WP-Cron is unreliable: Only runs when someone visits your site
Can cause performance issues: Runs during page loads
System cron is better: Runs on schedule regardless of traffic
More predictable: Runs exactly when scheduled
First, we need to disable WordPress's built-in cron system.
In RunCloud Dashboard:
Go to your WordPress application
Click on File Manager or use SSH terminal
Navigate to your WordPress root directory (usually /home/runcloud/webapps/[app-name]/public)
Edit wp-config.php:
Find wp-config.php in the root directory
Open it for editing
Add this line BEFORE the line that says /* That's all, stop editing! Happy publishing. */:
Example wp-config.php:
If you prefer using the file manager or SSH:
The file is at: /home/runcloud/webapps/[your-app-name]/public/wp-config.php
Add the same line as above

Option 1: Using RunCloud's Cron Job Manager (Easiest)
p: Access Cron Jobs in RunCloud:
Log into RunCloud dashboard
Go to your server
Look for Cron Jobs or Scheduled Tasks section
Click Add Cron Job or New Cron Job
Configure the Cron Job:
Command:
Replace [your-app-name] with your actual app name
Schedule: */15 * * * *(runs every 15 minutes)
Or */5 * * * * for every 5 minutes (more frequent)
Or 0 * * * * for every hour
User: Usually runcloud or rc(check RunCloud settings)
